citations.narrative:
The only water receptacle in a red-tailed hawk enclosure has accumulated algae and organic material, giving the water a
green hue and limiting the bird's access to potable water. Failure to provide potable water may expose birds to disease
risks. Water receptacles must be kept clean as often as necessary to ensure health and well-being and must be sanitized
in accordance with section 3.158 as often as necessary to keep them free of contamination.
Correct by 7/29/2024.

citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live birds.
citations.narrative:
The primary enclosures utilized to transport raptors do not feature external projecting rims or other devices to prevent
obstruction of the ventilation holes on the long faces and top of the enclosures. Inadequate ventilation during transport
may compromise respiration and cause undue stress. The sides of the transport enclosures with ventilation openings
must feature rims or similar devices large enough to provide 0.75 inches between the enclosure and anything adjacent to
it, unless 90% or greater of the surface area of the enclosure wall is open.
Correct by 8/9/24, or prior to transporting birds.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Tonya Hadjis, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist n

narrative:
3.156 
   
Watering 
The only water receptacle in a red-tailed hawk enclosure has accumulated algae and organic material, giving the water a 
green hue and limiting the bird's access to potable water. Failure to provide potable water may expose birds to disease 
risks. Water receptacles must be kept clean as often as necessary to ensure health and well-being and must be sanitized 
in accordance with section 3.158 as often as necessary to keep them free of contamination. 
 
Correct by 7/29/2024. 
3.162(b)(2) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live birds. 
The primary enclosures utilized to transport raptors do not feature external projecting rims or other devices to prevent 
obstruction of the ventilation holes on the long faces and top of the enclosures. Inadequate ventilation during transport 
may compromise respiration and cause undue stress. The sides of the transport enclosures with ventilation openings 
must feature rims or similar devices large enough to provide 0.75 inches between the enclosure and anything adjacent to 
it, unless 90% or greater of the surface area of the enclosure wall is open.  
 
Correct by 8/9/24, or prior to transporting birds. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Tonya Hadjis, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist n
